variant.question: The Basic Regulation refers to a...

options.text: Binding rule adopted by the European Parliament and the Council, establishing the EASA.
Binding rule adopted by the EASA, establishing Acceptable Means of Compliance.
Non-Binding rule adopted by EASA, establishing implementing Acts and Delegated Acts.
Non-Binding rule adopted by the European Commission, establishing aeronautical rules and basic standards.

variant.question: The regulatory material related to air safety and managed by EASA includes:

options.text: Hard and soft law
Hard norms and soft implementing rules
Hard rules and decrees
High requirements and low requirements

variant.question: What is the difference between hard and soft law?

options.text: Hard laws are legal obligations while soft laws only provide more details about the hard laws.
Hard laws can contain documents such as certification specifications and guidance material, while soft laws contain regulations and implementing rules.
Soft laws are the latest features fly-by-wire aircraft need to be fitted with, whereas hard laws refer mainly to mechanically driven flight controls.
Hard laws are applied by force to the operators whereas it is a choice to comply with soft laws or not.

variant.question: EASA recommends hard laws,...

options.text: including rules and regulations, delegated acts and implementing acts, and soft laws including certification specifications, acceptable means of compliance, and guidance material.
including acceptable means of compliance, guidance material and certification specifications, and soft laws including regulations, delegated acts, and implementing rules.
including certification specifications, and soft laws including implementing rules and guidance material.
including guidance materials, and soft laws including implementing rules and regulations, and implementing acts.

variant.question: Basic Regulation (EC) No 216/2008 applies to..

options.text: aircraft that are designed by an organisation for which EASA ensures safety oversight.
unmanned aircraft with an operating mass of up to 150 kg.
single and two-seater gyroplanes with a maximum take-off mass of up to 560 kg.
aircraft designed or modified for experimental purposes, and to be produced in limited numbers.

variant.question: The European Union Aviation Safety Agency is involved in proposing hard law, such as...

options.text: Regulations, Implementing Acts, and Delegated Acts, and publishing soft law, such as Acceptable Means of Compliance and Guidance Material.
Acceptable Means of Compliance and Guidance Material, and publishing soft law, such as Regulations, Implementing Acts, and Delegated Acts.
Acceptable Means of Compliance, and publishing soft law, such as Guidance Material.
Guidance Material, and publishing soft law, such as Acceptable Means of Compliance.

variant.question: Consider the regulations and acts associated with EASA. An Implementing Act is a...

options.text: binding act adopted by the European Commission for the implementation of the Basic Regulation.
non-binding technical standard adopted by the EASA which indicates the means to demonstrate compliance with the Basic Regulation.
non-binding act adopted by the European Parliament which enables the EASA to modify the Basic Regulation.
non-binding technical act adopted by the European Commission for the implementation of the Basic Regulation.

variant.question: An Implementing Rule (IR) developed by EASA and adopted by the European Commission is considered a:

options.text: Hard law.
Acceptable Means of Compliance.
Certification Specification.
Soft Law.

variant.question: In which area of Air Traffic Control in Europe does Eurocontrol have a logical and operationally essential role to play?

options.text: Air Traffic Flow Management in Europe.
National airspace management within Europe.
Regional air navigation planning in Europe.
Regulation of civil aviation in Europe.

variant.question:
EASA applies a new standard for type certification
Can NAAs accept or decline this new standard?

options.text: Normally NAAs cannot decline new standards because EASA has jurisdiction over new type certificates.
Yes, it depends on the NAAs discretion to accept or decline new EASA standards.
Yes, new EASA standards are recommendations and not binding.
After approval by the corresponding CAA, NAAs have to accept those new standards.

variant.question: What are EASA basic regulations made up of?

options.text: Binding legal obligations and non-binding specifications.
Soft law binding obligations.
Hard law non-binding obligations.
Non-binding legal obligations.

variant.question: What does EASA basic regulation refer to?

options.text: It refers to binding legal obligations and non-binding specifications.
It is made of soft law binding obligations.
It refers to non-binding legal obligations.
It is made of hard law non-binding obligations.

variant.question: What is the role of EASA?

options.text: EASA proposes implementing rules to the European Commission and promotes the highest common standards of safety and environmental protection in civil aviation.
EASA proposes rules to the National Aviation Authorities and promotes the highest common standards of safety and environmental protection in civil aviation.
EASA proposes guidelines to the aviation industry and promotes the highest common standards of safety and environmental protection in civil aviation.
EASA makes only rule propositions to the National Aviation Authorities without the obligation to implement these.

variant.question: EASA Regulatory Material. An AMC (Acceptable Means of Compliance):

options.text: Is not binding and other means may be utilised if preferred to demonstrate compliance with the applicable requirements.
Accompanies the Implementing Act and provides additional explanation to assist the application of the Basic Regulation and its Implementing Rules.
Is binding and should be adherred to by all relevant parties to whom it is deemed to apply.
May only be produced by EASA.

variant.question: EASA regulatory material. "Hard Law" includes:

options.text: Regulations, Delegated Acts, Implementing Acts and Implementing Rules.
Implementing Rules, Implementing Acts and Certification Specifications.
Guidance Material, Regulations, Delegated Acts and Implementing Acts.
Certification Specifications, Acceptable Means of Compliance and Guidance Material.

variant.question: What do you understand by “EASA certification specifications”?

options.text: They are non-binding technical standards, adopted by EASA, to meet the essential requirements of the basic regulation.
They are non-binding explanatory and interpretation materials on how to achieve the requirements contained in the basic regulation.
They are binding technical standards, adopted by EASA, to meet the essential requirements of the basic regulation.
They are non-binding special detailed technical specifications determined by the NAA for an aerodrome.

variant.question:
Which of the areas listed below fall within the scope of the Basic Regulation (Reg. (EC) No 216/2008) on common rules in the field of civil aviation and establishing the European Aviation Safety Agency?
1. Commercial Air Transport operations,2. Aerodrome operations,3. Unmanned aircraft with an operating mass 150 kg,4. Air Traffic Management organisations.

options.text: 1, 2 and 4
1, 3 and 4
1, 2 and 3
2, 3 and 4

variant.question: What is the role of the National Aviation Authorities (NAAs) in relation to EASA in the field of air operations?

options.text: EASA proposes Implementing Rules and the NAAs act as competent authorities.
EASA suggests rules to the NAAs, which they can reject or implement.
EASA is the Regulatory Authority and the NAAs can implement or reject the rules on air operations.
EASA provides safety recommendations to the NAAs, which implement their own rules.

variant.question: What does the structure of the regulatory material related to EASA involve?

options.text: Hard law and soft law
All the laws and regulations deriving from ICAO Annex 1
Only certification specifications
Compliance law and soft law

variant.question: What does the structure of the regulatory material related to EASA involve?

options.text: Unique structure of hard law (regulations, delegated acts, implementing acts, implementing rules) and soft law (certification specifications, acceptable means of compliance and guidance material).
Unique structure of laws.
Special guidance materials and regulations that harmonize and facilitate the regulatory structure of the agency.
Unique structure of soft law (regulations, delegated acts, implementing acts, implementing rules) and hard law (certification specifications, acceptable means of compliance and guidance material).

variant.question: What is correct regarding an AMC (Acceptable Means of Compliance)?

options.text: It is not binding and other means may be utilised if preferred to demonstrate compliance with the applicable requirements.
It is binding and should be adhered to by all relevant parties to whom it is deemed to apply.
It may only be produced by EASA.
It accompanies the Implementing Act and provides additional explanation to assist the application of the Basic Regulation and its Implementing Rules.

variant.question: An EASA implementing rule, adopted by the European Commission, is considered a/an...

options.text: hard law.
soft law.
acceptable means of compliance (AMC).
certification specification.
